speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: So I'm Michael Zargum, and I generally go by Zargum, so feel free to refer to me as that.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: This is Conrad, my daughter, who I am in charge of at the moment.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: She says hi.

text: Hopefully she will remain calm for the duration of this talk.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: So we're going to talk a bit about...
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: applied complex systems engineering for social impact a big part of this discussion is going to revolve around complexity and how we apply it for designing algorithms for community decision-making and this particular research is a collaboration between Myself my firm block science and the common stack, which is an open source project working on applications to community management
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: So the first thing I want to point out is that we really need to be able to scale social responsibility in order to make more effective decisions as communities.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: Right now, we're kind of stuck with a lot of challenges.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: Top-down governance systems are breaking down due to sort of
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: you know binary choices time box windows um just a lot of things that are sort of structurally problematic and rather than just saying the choices are bad we can sort of start to ask what the sort of phenomena or intrinsic properties of these systems are and maybe how we could work towards uh reorganizing ourselves to make better decisions and a pretty important concept here is
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: polycentric governance.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: It's something that is best read about in like Ostrom's work.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: For the purpose of this talk, I'll probably just kind of move into the technical stuff on complex systems, but from a motivational perspective, we very much want to find ways to use new tools to solve what we would consider old problems and not solve them ultimately forever, just sort of do a better job managing collective decision making.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: So in this context, I'm frequently asked to explain complex systems for people who don't have a complexity background.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: And I'm going to use it here anyway as a bridge.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: So we work with systems, they're just abstractions, they're representations of holes and their relationships with parts.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: And in particular, complex systems have
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: non-trivial and non-obvious relationships between the parts and each other and the whole in the sense that you can't sort of predict the system level behavior just from examining the part level behavior and sort of, in a sense, linearly adding it up.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: And in particular, social systems are a subset of complex systems, and we tend to look at economic and political economic systems.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: In particular, we're going to talk about applications from a field called DAOs, or Decentralized Autonomous Organizations, which are essentially just internet-based sort of collectives which use cryptographic technology as the backend to their decision-making procedures.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: In my work, in our practice, we're very careful to apply engineering principles, and in particular, we call out the institutional aspects of engineering
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: much the, you know, hey, we build stuff, but understanding a sort of holism, multi-specialization, understanding interfaces between parts, you know, managing complexity without trying to get rid of it.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: So, you know, understanding that the complexity can be placed under the hood and sort of taken care of, sort of understood, sensitivity tested,
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: et cetera, and then make a simple experience for the public without sort of simplifying the whole consideration to a sort of unsafe reduction.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: And in particular, we look at the full life cycle of the system we're trying to build.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: And a very important aspect of the engineering discipline is that
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: It's public good oriented.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: Actually, in a sense, the engineering field manages the relationship between society and technology.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: And again, this is the sort of institution of the profession.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: And in practice, there's a set of processes and procedures that help
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: us do this and tend to talk in terms of design and development and the way in which we do validation and verification.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: I definitely recommend anyone who's interested actually read a little bit about validation and verification, the differences between them and how they go together to create whole systems.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: Since we're working on social systems, it's really important to talk about how computational social science works and the relationship between the known and the unknown in our system models and how that relates to emergence.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: When dealing with individuals, we generally want to think in terms of open systems.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: meaning there's information outside of the system that's communicated into that system or expressed by the agent's choices, the actions they take or don't take.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: But that's private information that they hold that's maybe related to their private signals, but also might be their private preferences.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: And ultimately, there's a sort of
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: distributed state information spread out across the agents and that when they interact through a process they're going to have effects on each other they're going to have effects on the system state and even if the laws of motion or the aspects of the process model are deterministic because of this open system we're going to have a sort of non deterministic outcome we're going to basically have
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: a deterministic process as the consequence of your actions, but the actions themselves are non-deterministic, which is part of the reason why we get interesting emergence phenomena, because there's a feedback loop through the agents themselves and their choices of what to express.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: In a lot of ways, we can actually think of this as a signal processing problem.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: where the process model or the mechanisms that one designs are actually filtering or coloring the information that's being expressed by the agents participating in the system.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: So from a economics perspective, we tend to discuss this in terms of institutional economics, where we kind of zoom in on this sort of meso layer.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: We have a macro perspective, which is associated with system level behavior, sort of KPIs or goals.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: And we say, well, we want these high level rolled up statistics to move like this.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: But in fact, you can't mutate the high level statistics.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: They're just views or perspectives on a much more complex system.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: So you need to basically adapt or impose certain policies, and those policies get implemented as rules or incentives or procedures of some kind.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: And then, of course, that policy layer fills that sort of process model we had in the previous slide, and then agents behave.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: And they behave in a way that is influenced by those policies.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: They're influenced by their own perceptions of the system-level behavior and each other, and ultimately the actual system-level outcomes are emergent.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: And what we're trying to do is sort of design things in this policy goal setting layer, the rules, incentives, et cetera, that can help steer the system towards system level goals without assuming necessarily that those system level goals are defined sort of externally.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: So, you know, in most of my work, rather than saying, hey, I want people to do this,
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: I'm asking, hey, people want something to happen.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: We don't know what it is.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: But through a sort of more signal processing view of a decision-making protocol, we can actually design policies whose goal is to get that information and synthesize it, as opposed to simply force a particular outcome that maybe the policymaker has.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: So in the context of computer systems, we can talk about the difference between a constitution and the technology.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: So constitution is the definitions of the rules and processes and procedures
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: the in a sense the legal bits and the technology aspect is the implementation of it and what we find is that um there's an overlap here in this thing we call a computational constitution which is the subset of the um
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: of the procedures, rules, expectations, et cetera, that are actually enshrined in code.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: And as a result of that, you can sort of see a sort of programmability and an enforcement of those rules in code
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: while also relying on sort of an outer human process to adapt those rules and make changes as needed.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: And we tend to use access controls as an analogy here.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: So you have the right to do a certain thing under certain conditions, and you can have a computational state that manages your roles, what rights those roles
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: confer you and how to exercise them.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: Because this is a relatively short talk, I'm probably not going to go into too much detail.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: You could give a 30 minute talk just on this slide, but it's an overview of what we see happening in the sort of technological plus human sort of almost sort of cybernetic communities.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: Now, what's really interesting about these communities is that they're starting to proliferate in a way that's overlapping.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: So you see groups of people and projects working together on certain tasks, and then the outputs of those tasks
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: It's being used as inputs to future tasks.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: And you get a bunch of communities and projects interconnected in a sort of network of networks.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: I really like the simplicial complex representation of this because a lot of the times things are tuples.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: In particular though, there's an example here on the left, a project I've been working on is called Conviction Voting, and another one is called Community Inclusion Currencies.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: And there's like an overlap between the organizations that are working on these things.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: And so we can see that we have this,
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: complex structure and that more broadly we see a large number of these interconnected there's sort of many in the aragon ecosystem and in particular some data collected by this medigov project in particular this sub project is called govbase we're building a data set of lots of projects and the tools that they're using as well as their governance procedures and the
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: their licensing choices, et cetera.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: And one view of that dataset is this bipartite graph between projects and tools.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: And you can sort of see the projects that are using some of the same tools.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: Now I want to sort of zoom in on something a little bit more concrete for the purpose of this presentation.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: So one of the design patterns for these types of organizations is this quote unquote cyber physical commons, which is a design that I worked on with the common stack and it involves a handful of components and it largely includes the ability to
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: raise funds and make decisions to allocate those funds and to sort of escrow and review work in order to issue those funds to people who have completed tasks as proposed.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: This is a pretty standard set of questions.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: It's not exhaustive, but it's a good place to start when you are looking at sort of community management and you want to do some collaborative production and maintenance of what you've produced.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: So we realized that the governance part or the decision making of how to expend funds was a real blocker.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: Many projects have tried sort of standard voting procedures and really just not gotten the engagement levels or even just like the sense that people feel like they're being heard.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: And so we wanted to revisit the question of what voting is.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: And so as a complex system scientist,
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: control theorist, I ask this question in very formal terms.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: So we have signals on one side, we have signals on the other side, but it turns out the input signals are private, distributed, continuous, time varying.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: It's just everybody's preferences.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: And obviously that's a pretty high dimensional thing.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: And the output has to be a public centralized event.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: and to be honest like that's a huge dimensionality reduction so obviously there's no one unique solution to this problem and if anyone's familiar there's some like more canonical analysis of voting processes from arrow that says it's impossible for voting to meet
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: a set of fairness axioms.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: And this goes even beyond that by just saying, this is a massive dimensionality reduction.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: Therefore, there can't possibly be a sort of unique optimal solution to this problem.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: It's gonna depend on context and what this community is trying to accomplish, their norms, preferences, et cetera.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: So in practice, it's beyond even just choosing what the voting accounting procedure is, because when we have an algorithmic policy that determines an event from the input actions, we need to think about how one obtains and asserts their rights to participate.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: And in these systems, we also often have magnitude.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: So you might have a right to vote, but you also might have a quantity or sort of mass of voting power, depending on maybe your past contributions to the project or sort of other ways of modulating the difference between someone who sort of just showed up and joined and is new to the community versus sort of long standing contributor.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: where you don't want to overweight it and exclude the new people, which at the same time, you need to find a way to strike a balance in the decision-making.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: So we often do this by policies around not just obtaining the right to participate, but the magnitude of that right.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: Additionally, it's really important to understand who has the right to add or remove the actual options.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: So you look at a voting process and say, well, I have two choices and I hate both of them.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: It doesn't really matter that you have the right to participate in that voting process if you're not being offered a choice that's meaningful to you.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: In this sense, we say that, yeah, okay, the method of asserting and accounting of a vote is important, but so too is how one obtains that right and how
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: a potential choice in the first place.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: And so we again revisit the fact that there can't exist an optimal voting process.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: Instead, we have to really look at this from a contextual basis.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: The algorithm that we are using in our work here is called conviction voting, and it's essentially a leaky integrator or a low-pass filter.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: It just basically means that people are doing a kind of approval voting.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: They're taking whatever number of tokens they have.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: And that's their magnitude.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: And they are expressing them in favor of any number of proposals.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: So if I have 100 tokens, I might put 45 on proposal X, but I might put 55 on proposal Y or hold back the other 55 and look for another opportunity.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: But what I'm essentially doing is an approval voting or a weighted approval voting over a sort of open-ended list of proposals.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: A new proposal might arrive.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: In any case, the way that this algorithm works for allocating funding is essentially to charge up this battery or this capacitor, and when it surpasses a certain activation energy, a proposal passes, a bit like a neuron firing.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: So we have a sort of
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: inspired model for how we got to this algorithm in practice we build CAD CAD models so these are sort of hybrid sort of network agent based models we have participants and we have proposals we have private signals related to affinity and we sort of manage these data structures as Network X objects which are bipartite graphs and we can actually look at the way the system evolves over time and this is a quick experiment from
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: basically a video capture from one of these sort of agent-based dynamic network models.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: And the left side in red is all the participants.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: The size of the dot is how much magnitude they have.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: If you notice, there are new agents arriving on the left.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: There's more red dots appearing.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: There are new proposals arriving on the right.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: Those are the blue dots are candidates.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: Yellow dots are past but not yet completed.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: And green dots are completed projects.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: you can sort of see that he's charging up and there's a variation in the size of the dots on the right as well because you actually have different size requests for funding and we use a different um required support for projects that request larger amounts of funds so
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: Here's a snapshot of one run in this experiment.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: And you can see there's an accumulation of candidate funds, which is amount of funds being requested.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: Active funds are projects that are currently running.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: Completed funds are the funds associated with projects that have
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: been completed and killed means the project didn't maintain enough support and got dropped off the list and failed means a project was actually funded but then it was not successfully executed and there's a there's a sentiment model in the background that gives a feedback loop for the sort of future available funds so if you're not actually succeeding in passing proposals and completing them you're going to see a depletion in the available funds to allocate
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: The nice thing about this is it's not just simulations.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: We have had a live test case running with onehive.org for the last few months, and you can check that out.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: If you happen to have honey tokens or wanted to buy them, you can even participate in voting on these proposals.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: The way that that organization works is that the organization itself owns some tokens that they can sell, but they also
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: have a procedure through which funds for projects are given in Honey.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: So largely the Honey holders are people who have been contributing projects over time, and they use that token to assert their right to participate in voting for future proposals that get funded.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: And actually this org is managing tens of thousands of dollars.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: Actually at the moment it looks like it's over 100,000, but that's actually recent.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: So apparently people are really enjoying this work.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: A little bit of an overview to wrap up this point.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: The solution, even the test case in Honey, is not exhaustive here.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: We've left a lot of other components up for future adaptation.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: We add a proposal for consideration, anyone can do it.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: Risk is proposal spam, but we really haven't had that issue because it's community managed.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: Could be in the future as it scales up.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: You can vote on proposals, the tokens are transferable, they have magnitude.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: There's always a risk of plutocracy here.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: There are ways to limit this through implementation of strong identity like BrightID or to use a threshold that says if you have more than a certain amount,
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: tokens then you get a allocation of votes but that's the same for everyone who's above the threshold.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: These are ways of addressing these concerns if they become a problem and you know furthermore we have issues with potentially people not doing the work they agreed to do but there are procurement and bidding systems like Giveth.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: You can have escrows and independent review processes
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: is also supported by tools like Giveth.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: And governance at the sort of, we'll call it like council level is also possible using another layer of access control and role-based tokens.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: This is scaling up to a big, much larger test case run by Aragon.org, which is actually running currently.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: When I first wrote this presentation, it hadn't yet launched, but it launched this week.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: I would recommend checking out.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: It's a much larger organization
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: The Aragon project has had a very, very large launch a couple of years ago.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: The tokens that can be used for voting in this pilot are very widely distributed across a large number of people.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: And it would be interesting to analyze the data that comes out of this six-week snapshot pilot on the Aragon network.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: And so I will sort of close on this discussion of computer aided governance.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: So a lot of my work relates to digital twins, which is basically building computational models that marry theory and data to give us visibility into the sort of trajectories of complex systems.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: And what we observe is that when these types of models and they do exist,
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: are opaque and proprietary in governments and corporations they become effectively tools of authoritarian control but when they're open source and transparent and they're sort of part of a community project you can sort of see them as sense-making tools and they can provide support for data-driven discourse and collective decision-making where instead of just saying well if we do this i think that's going to happen
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: And someone else says, well, no, if we do that, this other thing is going to happen.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: And you just argue about the consequences of the decision.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: It can be very difficult to actually make progress.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: But if you have some shared open source tools that help you say, hey, it looks like if we do this, this will probably happen, but that might happen.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: How's the trade-off look?
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: What do we want?
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: And so I'm a big advocate for the sort of democracy in the information age being driven by open source algorithmic policymaking.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: And it starts by understanding that all algorithms essentially have some
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: a subjective assumptions in the way that they're approached even the quote-unquote model-free um algorithms are still compressing information that's buried in data and the data itself has some some properties maybe some biases a wide range of of of things that it's important to address and understand what assumption you're making and bring that up to the forefront when you're going to be using those algorithms in some form or another to sort of
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: either govern decision-making processes or when the decision-making processes output algorithms or procedures.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: So if you're interested in any of this stuff, I do work through the Vienna University of Economics and Business as an affiliated researcher.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: I run a design firm called Block Science.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: We have a token engineering discipline on the rise.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: We have a Discord and a growing community applying these complex
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: systems concepts to designing tokenized systems and the common stack, which is the project from which this particular research was drawn.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: And our tooling is called CADCAD.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: It's a Python open source tool for generalized dynamical systems.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: If you wanted to follow up on any of these things, here's some information about how to connect with these three organizations.

text: So apologies if I ran a little long.

speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: Thank you very much, Zargum.

speaker: SPEAKER_05

speaker: SPEAKER_05
